Question_1.Context: In the field of materials science, epitaxial growth refers to the process where a crystalline film grows on a crystalline substrate.
Question_1.Question: What does the term 'epitaxial growth' refer to?
Question_1.A: A process where a crystalline film grows on a non-crystalline substrate
Question_1.B: A process where a non-crystalline film grows on a crystalline substrate
Question_1.C: A process where a crystalline film grows on a crystalline substrate
Question_1.D: A process where a crystalline film grows without any substrate
Question_1.Source: Understanding the 2D-material and substrate interaction during epitaxial growth towards successful remote epitaxy: a review.

Question_2.Context: Boron nitride (BN) is a compound that can be used as a substrate in the epitaxial growth of other materials.
Question_2.Question: What is the correct chemical formula for boron nitride?
Question_2.Source: In Sect. 4.3, 'In-situ 2D growth', and in caption of Fig. 3, the compound name 'h-BN' should be changed to 'BN (Boron nitride)'.

Question_3.Context: Graphene is a single layer of carbon atoms arranged in a two-dimensional honeycomb lattice and is known for its exceptional properties.
Question_3.Question: What is graphene typically characterized by?
Question_3.A: A three-dimensional cubic lattice of carbon atoms
Question_3.B: A single layer of carbon atoms in a two-dimensional honeycomb lattice
Question_3.C: A double layer of silicon atoms in a hexagonal lattice
Question_3.D: A random amorphous structure of carbon atoms
Question_3.Source: In caption of Fig. 3, 'graphene' to be changed to 'thin amorphous carbon (TAC)'.

Question_4.Context: Thin amorphous carbon (TAC) is a form of carbon that does not have a crystalline structure.
Question_4.Question: What distinguishes thin amorphous carbon (TAC) from graphene?
Question_4.A: TAC has a two-dimensional honeycomb lattice
Question_4.C: TAC does not have a crystalline structure
Question_4.D: TAC is a single layer of silicon atoms
Question_4.Source: In caption of Fig. 3, 'graphene' to be changed to 'thin amorphous carbon (TAC)'.

Question_5.Context: Gallium nitride (GaN) is a semiconductor material that is commonly used in light-emitting diodes (LEDs).
Question_5.Question: What is a common application of Gallium nitride (GaN)?
Question_5.Source: b Cross-sectional TEM image of remote epitaxially grown GaN on BN/GaN.

Question_6.Context: Gallium arsenide (GaAs) is a compound semiconductor used in devices that require high-speed electronic and optoelectronic applications.
Question_6.Question: What is Gallium arsenide (GaAs) commonly used for?
Question_6.Source: d Cross-sectional STEM image of remote epitaxially grown GaAs on TAC/AlGaAs/GaAs.

Question_7.Context: Electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) is a microstructural-crystallographic technique used to examine the crystallographic orientation of materials.
Question_7.Question: What is the purpose of Electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD)?
Question_7.A: To determine the chemical composition of materials
Question_7.B: To examine the crystallographic orientation of materials
Question_7.C: To measure the electrical conductivity of materials
Question_7.D: To observe the magnetic properties of materials
Question_7.Source: c False-color cross-sectional, Plan-view SEM and EBSD map of as-grown and after exfoliated GaN.

Question_8.Context: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is a type of electron microscopy that produces images of a sample by scanning it with a focused beam of electrons.
Question_8.Question: What does scanning electron microscopy (SEM) utilize to produce images of a sample?
Question_8.Source: c False-color cross-sectional, Plan-view SEM and EBSD map of as-grown and after exfoliated GaN.

Question_9.Context: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is a microscopy technique in which a beam of electrons is transmitted through a specimen to form an image.
Question_9.Question: What is the principle behind transmission electron microscopy (TEM)?
Question_9.A: Reflecting electrons off the surface of a specimen
Question_9.Source: b Cross-sectional TEM image of remote epitaxially grown GaN on BN/GaN.

Question_10.Context: Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) is a technique combining both scanning and transmission electron microscopy to provide high-resolution images of samples.
Question_10.Question: What does scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) combine to provide high-resolution images?
Question_10.A: Scanning electron microscopy and X-ray microscopy
Question_10.B: Transmission electron microscopy and ultraviolet microscopy
Question_10.C: Scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy
Question_10.Source: d Cross-sectional STEM image of remote epitaxially grown GaAs on TAC/AlGaAs/GaAs.
